title: In which book did Aristotle say that human beings are curious by nature? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don't know. I have zero knowledge of Western Philosophy. Some time, I want to read Socrates, Nietzsche, Marcus Aurelius and Plato. Don't know when. I have just read a few essays of Ralph Waldo Emerson. That's about it. Every thing, I am writing is from my own life and experiences. If you know your own mind and life- inside out- you pretty much can understand every different interpretation of life. Once you know yourself- you know every thing. Hence it is written on the forecourt of the temple of Apollo at Delphi. Know thyself! Know thyself - Wikipedia All the very best! Regards, Swaroopa.
Aristotle talks about the human desire to know in the Book I of his Metaphysics. Interestingly, he quickly distinguished seeking knowledge from “mere” curiosity (which he doesn’t admire).
